Name:  ___             Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
transient weakness/aphasia, failure to thrive  
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Blood transfusion (2 units pRBC)

 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo ___-speaking woman with ___ UTIs, DM, Graves, 
pAF, recent admission for ischemic colitis, presents with 
transient/resolved episode of weakness and speech difficulty, 
also with chronic decline in ADLs per family, found to have 
anemia to 7.4 from baseline 8.8 in ___, admitted for failure
to thrive.  
 
When speaking to the patient, she cannot give many details about 
what happened ___. She states she remembers walking to the 
bathroom and falling down on her R side without loss of 
consciousness or head strike. She was able to get up with the 
help of her family and since has just felt tired and fatigued.
Denies any other symptoms. On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, 
loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, 
lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies 
difficulties producing or comprehending speech. Denies focal 
weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel or bladder 
incontinence or retention.  
 
On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or 
chills. No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies 
cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, 
palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or 
abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No
dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash. She does 
also endorse a couple days of foul smelling urine. She was 
initially seen at osh where pt found to have hematocrit of 23 
with guaiac negative stool. She had imaging including CXR, CT 
head and C-spine, XR hip which were unremarkable. Patient noted 
to be incontinent of urine shortly after arrival to ED which is
not baseline.  
 
Collateral history from the family reveals more of a chronic 
decline. 
For the past year or so has been requiring more help with her 
ADLs, including taking medications, dressing herself and feeding 
herself. In addition, over the past few months she has started 
to speak less frequently though when she does speak there are no 
errors in her speech. She also has been more confused for the
past few months, often not knowing whether it is morning or 
night. Weakness on ___ is acute.

Per son, HCP: Pt has a home healthcare aid, visits patient every 
day from 7a-10am. 10am pt goes to adult day care M-F. Stays at 
the day care until 330pm. When pt returns home, the same home 
healthcare aid comes in and prepares dinner and gets her ready 
for bed. Pts son, HCP ___ lives with her but does not handle 
all her care. ___ morning she felt very weak, unable to 
stand up, acute onset. ___ could not send her to the daycare 
due to weakness as patient couldn't even walk. Her blood sugar 
at this time was ___. ___ stayed home to watch her. ___ 
morning, pt went to the bathroom and was in there for 10 minutes 
before ___ walked into the find her on the floor. Per ___, 
pt
told her that she didn't fall and she was unsure how she ended 
up on the floor. Per ___, pt is usually not confused and has 
no dementia. Incontinence started in ___ and weakness 
started ___. 
 
Of note, she had recent admission in ___ for lower abdominal 
pain and bloody stools and was thought to have ischemic colitis. 


 
In the ED:  
Initial vital signs were notable for: 98 72 132/72 14 96% RA  
Exam notable for: AOx2 person and place, motor ___ b/l upper and 
___, sensation diminished rle, smile symmetric, no dysarthria or 
aphasia.  
Labs were notable for: hgb 7.4, WC 6.2, Plt 360, normal chem 10, 
trop 0.02 x 2, LFTs WNL, UA with 8 WBC, pos Nitr
Studies performed include: CXR, CT Head, CT C-spine, XR Hip
(from OSH)  
Patient was given: IV ceftriaxone, metformin, pravastatin, 
losartan, omeprazole  
Consults: neurology  
Vitals on transfer: 72 150/70 15 100% RA  
 
Upon arrival to the floor, the patient  is resting comfortably 
and is a little confused. 

Review of Systems:  
==================  
Complete ROS obtained and is otherwise negative.  

 
Past Medical History:
- Atrial fibrillation, paroxysmal  
- Hypertension  
- Diabetes mellitus II  
- Asthma  
- Obesity  
- Graves Disease  
- Right knee DJD  
- Mild esophagitis seen on EGD ___  
- history of UTI

Social History:

Family History:

Physical Exam:
=============================
EXAM ON ADMISSION
=============================
VITALS: T 98.4, HR 78, BP 161/85, RR 18, 98% Ra  
GENERAL: Alert and interactive. In no acute distress. AOx2- ___ 
currently   
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic.Sclera anicteric and without 
injection. Moist mucous membranes, good dentition. Oropharynx is 
clear.  
NECK: Thyroid is normal in size and texture, no nodules. No 
cervical lymphadenopathy. No JVD.  
CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate. Audible S1 and S2. No 
murmurs/rubs/gallops.  
LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally w/appropriate breath 
sounds appreciated in all fields. No wheezes, rhonchi or rales. 
No increased work of breathing.  
ABDOMEN: Normal bowels sounds, non distended, non-tender to deep 
palpation in all four quadrants. No organomegaly.  
EXTREMITIES: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. Pulses DP/Radial 
2+ bilaterally.    
NEUROLOGIC: CN2-12 intact. ___ strength throughout. Normal 
sensation. Gait is normal. AOx3.

no organomegaly, no rebound or guarding  
GU: No foley  
Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis, 
slight left knee swelling compared to right. TEDs in place 
Neuro: Face grossly symmetric with mild word slurring. Moving 
all limbs with purpose against gravity. Left foot dorsiflexion 
___, plantarflexion ___. Mild intention tremor of left hand.

IMAGING
=============================
Radiologic Data (OSH):

___ CTA Head/Neck
"There are acute pulmonary emboli in the right upper lobe 
subsegmental branches. 
  
NECT: 
Chronic infarcts of the right frontal lobe, bilateral thalami, 
bilateral cerebellum are seen. Well-defined hypodensities in the 
centrum semiovale likely represent infarcts, may represent 
subacute or chronic infarcts, similar to prior. Calcific 
densities in the right insula, left parafalcine left parietal 
lobe are re-demonstrated. Findings consistent with moderate to 
severe chronic small vessel ischemic changes. Generalized brain 
parenchymal atrophy. No intracranial hemorrhage. 
  
Component of acute infarct would be difficult to exclude given 
extensive changes above. 
  
___ CTA HEAD: 
Atherosclerotic disease bilateral cavernous segments ICAs, 
withareas of mild-to-moderate narrowing. Suggestion of 1.5 mm 
inferiorly projecting aneurysm along the right paraclinoid ICA. 
Mild narrowing V4 segment left vertebral artery. Mild narrowing 
left P3 segment, P4 segment on the left. 
There is severe narrowing left P1 segment. Mild narrowing right 
P1 segment.  Patent right PCOM. 3.1 cm irregular round 
calcification adjacent to the A2 segments ACA, with some of the 
branching coursing near, may represent unrelated falcine 
calcification or largely thrombosed aneurysm.
MRA brain without contrast would be helpful in further 
evaluation. Additional punctate calcification in the left 
parietal lobe sulcus, no vascular connections near it, may be 
sequela of prior inflammatory, infectious or vascular insult. 
  
Otherwise, the vessels of circle of ___ and their major 
branches are patent without evidence ofocclusion or aneurysm 
formation. Hypoplastic right A1 segment.  The principal dural 
venous sinuses are patent. 
  
___ CTA NECK: 
The carotid arteries are patent from their origin with moderate  
atherosclerotic plaque at the carotid bifurcation causing 
minimal to mild proximal ICA stenosis.  The vertebral arteries 
are patent from their origins without evidence of stenosis, 
dissection or occlusion. 
  
___ CT perfusion: 
CT source perfusion data is not available at the time of 
interpretation. Rapid data is not available at the time of 
interpretation. On color maps of cerebral blood flow, volume and 
T-max, there is symmetric,bilateral zone involving posteromedial 
both parietal lobes with decreased cerebral blood volume, 
matching decreased cerebral blood flow and increased T-max, 
extending into the posterior left temporal lobe. Given 
involvement on both sides, findings may represent technique 
related artifact or infarct. No penumbra. 
  
OTHER: Small lung nodules, largest measures 4 mm. Paraseptal 
emphysema. Mild bronchial wall thickening, consistent with 
peribronchial inflammation. There is a 1.5 cm left thyroid 
nodule. Additional smaller thyroid nodules. There are acute 
pulmonary emboli in the right upper lobe subsegmental branches. 
Moderate paranasal sinus mucosal thickening. Clear mastoids. 
Degenerative changes spine. Mild anterolisthesis C4-C5, likely 
degenerative. 

___ bilateral lower extremity U/S: Negative for DVT

___ MRI head and neck without contrast (impression)
1. Partially degraded study due to motion artifact. 
2. Large acute to subacute infarct involving the right 
cerebellar hemisphere with smaller acute to subacute infarcts of 
the right pons and medial right superior parietal lobule. 
3. Multiple old bilateral thalamic, bilateral cerebellar 
hemisphere and right frontal infarcts. 
4. Generalized parenchymal volume loss, likely age related. 

___ ECHOCARDIOGRAM
The left atrial volume index is moderately increased. There is 
mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left 
ventricular cavity size is normal. Due to suboptimal technical 
quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully 
excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal 
(LVEF = 70%). The right ventricular free wall thickness is 
normal. Right ventricular chamber size is normal with normal 
free wall contractility. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, 
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No 
aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The 
pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. 
There is no pericardial effusion. 

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
there is no obvious change but the technically suboptimal nature 
of both studies precludes definitive comparison. A small 
secundum atrial septal defect was noted in the prior study 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY:
========================
___ year old ___-speaking female with a history of 
atrial fibrillation (not on anticoagulation), HTN, HLD, DMII, 
Graves disease, and cognitive impairment with recent admission 
in ___ for presumed ischemic colitis, admitted for weakness 
and fall (FTT) w/ acute development of an ischemic stroke s/p 
tPA, with course complicated by a UTI and acute on chronic 
anemia.

ACTIVE ISSUES:
========================
Ischemic stroke:
Pt was on the medicine service for workup of a fall and 
cognitive decline when she was found to have deteriorated 
clinical status on the floor with muteness, lack of interaction, 
and L gaze deviation resulting in a code stroke ___ morning, 
s/p tpa ___ @ 8:30am and monitoring in the neuro ICU. MRI with 
R cerebellar infarct, punctate R pons, and R parafalcine infarct 
likely cardioembolic in setting of known afib not on 
anticoagulation (and echo with small ASD). EEG negative for 
seizure activity. She was initiated on Apixaban and 
Atorvastatin. She has improved significantly. Discharge exam 
notable for a mild intention tremor of the left hand without 
obvious dysmetria, along with mild left lower extremity 
weakness. Plan to follow up with neurology as outpatient in the 
next ___ weeks. 

Atrial fibrillation with RVR:
Known history of non-valvular atrial fibrillation not on 
anticoagulation, treated with Diltiazem for rate control. 
Immediately prior to the patient's stroke, she developed atrial 
fibrillation with RVR which improved with IV Metoprolol. Pt's 
home Diltiazem 300mg PO ER once daily was fractionated and 
ultimately increased to 120mg q6 for rate control. Overnight 
___ the patient spontaneously flipped back into sinus rhythm 
with HRs in the ___. Her Diltiazem was decreased to 90mg q6. 
Will discharge on home dose. 

Acute on chronic microcytic anemia:
Pt with chronic and progressive iron deficiency anemia, baseline 
hemoglobin 10.5. Admitted in ___ with hematochezia and acute 
anemia s/p unremarkable colonoscopy; etiology attributed to 
ischemic colitis. Discharge hemoglobin 8.8 and prescribe iron 
supplementation and maintained on home PPI. On this admission, 
her hemoglobin was 7.4 and downtrended to 6.5 requiring 2 units 
of pRBCs (___) with appropriate rise in hemoglobin. She was 
guaiac positive (___) without episodes of melena or 
hematochezia. GI was consulted and cleared her for 
anticoagulation. Given stability of hemoglobin without evidence 
of active bleeding, repeat EGD was deferred to the outpatient 
setting. Of note, her ferrous gluconate was held at discharge 
due to constipation and should be restarted when this resolves. 

Urinary tract infection:
Admission UA +nitrite, culture with pansensitive e.coli. Family 
endorsed altered mental status and urinary incontinence at home. 
She was treated with Ceftriaxone x5 days (___). 

Constipation:
Pt did not pass a bowel movement until ___ s/p miralax, senna 
and a bisacodyl suppository. She denies abdominal pain and her 
abdominal exam is benign. Constipation likely secondary to 
decreased mobility and PO intake. She was continued on this 
bowel regimen and may require an enema in the next ___ hours 
if this does not resolve. Of note, her ferrous gluconate was 
held at discharge due to constipation and should be restarted 
when this resolves. 

Urinary retention:
Urinary incontinence:
Pt with history of incontinence (onset ___, worse just prior 
to admission likely ___ UTI though still present. She also 
required intermittent straight catheterizations for urinary 
retention likely secondary to traumatic foley placement (___) 
and immobility; this resolved by discharge. 

Decreased PO intake:
Etiology unclear (see above re: outpatient endoscopy). Per 
nutrition recommendations, pt initiated on multivitamin with 
minerals and glucerna TID. 

CHRONIC ISSUES:
========================
Hypertension: Held home losartan during hospitalization and at 
discharge, continued on diltiazem for afib with SBPs in the 
100s-120s. 

Hyperlipidemia: switched home pravastatin to atorvastatin

Diabetes Mellitus II: A1c 6.4, held home metformin, did not 
require insulin sliding scale. 

Grave's Disease: TSH 1.1 on this admission.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
========================

Discharge hemoglobin 8.4

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ were admitted to ___ 
___ ___ felt weak and were having difficulty speaking. A cat 
scan of your head showed that ___ had a stroke, caused by low 
blood flow to parts of your brain. ___ were given medication for 
the stroke and many of the symptoms improved!

While ___ were here, ___ also had anemia, or low red blood 
counts. We gave ___ a blood transfusion to increase your blood 
counts. Your heart rate was also irregular but this improved 
with medication.

It was a pleasure taking part in your care! We wish ___ all the 
best with your future health.

Sincerely,
The medicine team at ___
 
Followup Instructions:

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
